stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 4 hours ago. Review the patient's chart and determine the appropriate actions, potential condition, and parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
1400: Patient reports increasing abdominal pain rated 7/10. States pain is different from post-op pain. Skin is cool and clammy.
1415: Notified Dr. Smith of patient's condition and new orders received.
1430: Patient received prescribed pain medication.
1500: Patient reports pain is now 9/10. BP 90/50, HR 120, RR 24, SpO2 92% on room air. Abdomen is firm and distended. Dressing is dry and intact with no visible signs of bleeding. Urine output via Foley catheter has been minimal (15 mL) over the past two hours. Lung sounds are clear bilaterally. Patient is increasingly anxious and restless.
1515: Continued monitoring of vital signs and patient comfort.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Anxious, restless.
Skin: Cool, clammy.
Abdomen: Firm, distended, tender to palpation.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, weak peripheral pulses.
Neuro: Alert and oriented, but increasingly agitated.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Goals: Manage pain, maintain hemodynamic stability, monitor for complications.
Interventions: Administer pain medication as prescribed. Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes. Assess abdominal distention and tenderness. Monitor urine output. Prepare for potential surgical intervention.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
• Hydromorphone 2mg IV q2hr PRN pain
  • Ondansetron 4mg IV q6hr PRN nausea
  • Normal Saline 1000mL IV bolus

actions.text: Prepare the patient for exploratory laparotomy.
Reposition the patient to a high-Fowler's position.

rationale.correct: The patient is exhibiting signs of hypovolemic shock, likely due to intra-abdominal bleeding post-operatively. Administering a rapid fluid bolus will help to restore circulating volume and improve blood pressure. Preparing the patient for exploratory laparotomy is necessary to identify and control the source of bleeding. Monitoring urine output is crucial to assess renal perfusion and the effectiveness of fluid resuscitation. Assessing peripheral pulses will also help to evaluate tissue perfusion and the severity of shock.
rationale.incorrect: Administering an antiemetic will not address the underlying cause of the patient's hypovolemic shock. Repositioning the patient will not improve their hemodynamic status. Monitoring pain level is important for patient comfort but is not the priority in this situation. Monitoring bowel sounds is not directly related to the immediate management of hypovolemic shock.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Correct. The patient's hypotension and tachycardia suggest hypovolemia, which can be addressed with a fluid bolus to increase circulating volume.
Correct. The increasing abdominal pain and distention, along with unstable vital signs, suggest a possible intra-abdominal bleed requiring surgical intervention.
Incorrect. While nausea is possible, it is not the priority. Hemodynamic instability needs to be addressed first.
Incorrect. Repositioning will not address the underlying issue of hypovolemia or potential bleeding.

Correct. The patient's vital signs (hypotension, tachycardia), clinical presentation (cool, clammy skin, abdominal distention), and lab results (elevated lactate) are consistent with hypovolemic shock.
Incorrect. While shortness of breath and chest pain can be symptoms of pulmonary embolism, the patient's abdominal pain and distention are more indicative of an intra-abdominal issue.
Incorrect. While possible after surgery, the patient's abdominal distention and vital sign changes are more significant than a wound issue alone.
Incorrect. The patient's clear lung sounds and lack of respiratory symptoms make pneumonia unlikely.
Correct. Urine output is a sensitive indicator of renal perfusion and overall hemodynamic status. Decreased urine output suggests inadequate circulating volume.
Incorrect. While pain management is important, monitoring urine output and peripheral pulses are higher priorities in assessing hemodynamic stability.
Correct. Peripheral pulses provide information about tissue perfusion, which is compromised in hypovolemic shock. Weak or absent pulses indicate poor circulation.
Incorrect. Bowel sounds are not directly related to the immediate assessment and management of hypovolemic shock.

clinicalPearls: In post-operative patients, sudden deterioration in vital signs, especially hypotension and tachycardia, should raise suspicion for hypovolemic shock.
Abdominal distention and increasing pain following abdominal surgery can indicate intra-abdominal bleeding.
Elevated lactate levels can indicate tissue hypoperfusion and anaerobic metabolism, supporting the diagnosis of shock.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on pain management and missing the signs of hypovolemic shock.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize assessing hemodynamic stability based on vital signs, physical exam findings, and lab results. Recognize that pain management is important but not the immediate priority in this situation.

mnemonic.title: SHOCK
mnemonic.expansion: Skin (cool, clammy), Hypotension, Output (decreased urine), Compensatory (tachycardia, tachypnea), Kill (treat quickly)
